overview: VS Code 1.103 adds new model availability options in chat (GPT-5 and GPT-5 mini), introduces chat checkpoints for restoring prior conversation/workspace states, and revamps the tool picker experience. It also improves terminal auto-approval settings, strengthens agent reliability around tasks/terminals, and expands productivity features such as Git worktree support.

detailed_explanation.title: New model options in chat
bullets: Adds GPT-5 availability in VS Code chat for paid GitHub Copilot plans, selectable via the model picker.
Adds GPT-5 mini availability as a faster, more cost-efficient variant (noted as part of an update).
The article references prompt improvements for GPT-5 added in an update release.

detailed_explanation.title: Chat checkpoints
bullets: Introduces checkpoints (setting(chat.checkpoints.enabled)) to restore earlier conversation states and revert workspace edits to that point.
After restoring a checkpoint, the notes state that you can redo the action as well.

detailed_explanation.title: Tool picker and tool limits
bullets: Revamps the tool picker UI using a tree view that supports collapsing/expanding and sticky scrolling.
Adds an experimental tool grouping mode to work around the 128-tools-per-request limit by grouping tools and letting the model activate tool groups.
The tool grouping behavior is configurable via setting(github.copilot.chat.virtualTools.threshold).

detailed_explanation.title: Terminal auto-approve evolution
bullets: Improves terminal auto-approve settings and migrates from separate allow/deny settings to a consolidated setting(chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove).
Adds support for regex flags (for example, case-insensitive matching) and clarifies sub-command vs full command-line matching.
Logs auto-approve reasoning to the Terminal Output channel (with a future UI surfacing noted).

detailed_explanation.title: Agent reliability for tasks and terminals
bullets: Agent mode detects when a task/command requests user input and surfaces options in chat for confirmation.
Improves task error detection using problem matchers so errors are surfaced based on matcher results.
Adds output polling so the agent waits for tasks/background terminals to complete, prompting the user if a command runs long.

detailed_explanation.title: Productivity: Git worktrees
bullets: Adds Git worktree support (setting(git.detectWorktrees)) to work on multiple branches simultaneously.
Updates the Source Control Repositories view to better distinguish repositories, submodules, and worktrees, and to show relationships.

detailed_explanation.title: Chat rendering and math support
bullets: Adds preview support for rendering math in chat responses via KaTeX (setting(chat.math.enabled)).
Adds OS notifications for user action required in chat (setting(chat.notifyWindowOnConfirmation)).

key_changes: GPT-5 and GPT-5 mini become available in the VS Code model picker for chat.
Chat checkpoints to restore earlier chat/workspace states.
Revamped tool picker UI and experimental tool grouping beyond the 128-tool limit.
Terminal auto-approve settings consolidated and enhanced with regex flags and better matching controls.
Improved agent awareness and reliability for tasks/terminals, including input detection and output polling.
Git worktree support for working on multiple branches simultaneously.
impact: Copilot users gain more model choices and better recovery workflows via checkpoints when experimenting with multi-file edits.
Users with many MCP servers/tools benefit from the tool picker overhaul and experimental tool grouping to avoid the 128-tool cap.
Teams running agent-driven tasks should see fewer stalls and clearer prompts when commands require input or run long.
Git users can adopt worktrees for parallel development without constant branch switching.
caveats: Tool grouping is explicitly marked experimental and is controlled by a threshold setting; exact stability/rollout guarantees are not stated in the article.
GPT-5 availability is described as rolling out to paid plans; exact rollout timing for all users is not stated in the article.
Math support is described as preview and is controlled by a setting.
insights: A central theme is scaling agent workflows: more tools, more automation, and more safeguards for long-running or interactive commands.
Checkpoints reflect a recognition that agent-driven edits can be exploratory and benefit from easy rollback to ‘known good’ states.
Model availability updates are paired with UX and reliability work, suggesting an emphasis on operationalizing AI features rather than just adding models.
